lines.text: The pleasure does not lie in the end itself. It's in the pleasurable steps to that end.
I'm so frightened and confused. I cannot think. I cannot even understand your thinking.
It is very bad of me! But I cannot help myself! He's so tall!
Are you gonna sit there with your bare face hangin' out and tell me you never heard of Tanabata?
This is the first liquid rice I have ever run into!

[Major Gruver is entering Joe Kelly's Japanese home for the first time]
Hey, off with the shoes. You don't wear shoes in a Japanese house.
Okay, comin' off... What about the pants?

watching, as a Japanese man spends a lot of time carefully making a cup of tea]
He makes such a production of everything.
The pleasure does not lie in the end itself... it's the pleasurable steps *to* that end.

[pointing to some large rocks right off the seashore]
You see the rope between the rocks?
Yeah?
That is a Shinto sign, showing they are married.

[slightly confused]
What, the rocks?
Yes... they've been together so long, our people thought it was time they should get married. They look well together, don't you think?
Yeah, they make a handsome little couple!
You know what I saw yesterday? I saw two rocks that just got married.

[slightly confused]
You what?
I saw two rocks that got married. And they looked very happy together, too.
Oh, I'll bet they did.
What are you really afraid of, Miss Webster? You don't think it would enter Major Gruver's mind to marry a Japanese girl?
I don't know.

Then permit me to reassure you. I think Major Gruver is brave, but, uh, not so brave enough to face the censure that would result from such a marriage. As for our famous, honored Hana-ogi, there are many Japanese - most of them, in fact - who look upon marriage to an Occidental with as much distaste as your people do to one of us.

[continues]
I do not feel that way, but then I have had the privilege of traveling in your country and knowing some great people there. And I am especially conscious at this moment that beauty is not confined to any one race.

[watching a traditional Japanese puppet performance about two doomed lovers]
It is custom for lovers to die together when they can no longer face life.

[dreamily]
It is so beautiful...
"Beautiful"? They're gonna' die, aren't they?

[dreamily]
They will live in another world, on a beautiful lake, floating always together, like water lily.

[makes a face]
Sure.
